https://github.com/lesscpy/lesscpy/blob/38c5661074de317314fcce4ee7aa7c7f0c164c1b/lesscpy/lessc/utility.py#L29

items.title: Bad version sequence
items.body:
Back in Oct 2016 you increased the version to 0.12.0 in 56c16b809c48f2c and now in Dec 2017 you have gone back to 0.11.2 in 10919f6a9fe4151

I'm not sure why the earlier commit doesn't show in the master/lesscpy/init.py history but v0.12.0 was previously visible in pypi, now going back to 0.11.2 breaks packaging systems that had previously installed 0.12.0. Due to 0.12.0 no longer existing it leaves the current version as less than existing installed version.

items.title: Please have the dependency list in setup.py
items.body: For example, it requires ```six``` and ```ply```, they aren't mentioned.

items.title: Output doesn't make intermediary directories
items.body:
For example, if the dir `bar` doesn't exist, this fails:

```
lesscpy foo.less /bar/foo.css
```

Where this will work:

```
lessc foo.less /bar/foo.css
```

This is biting me for a django static compiler issue, and would be glad to add the functionality if it can be rolled in.

items.title: updating pypi with support for 3.5?
items.body:
Thanks for all the hard work. Saw that the git repo has been updated to support Python 3.5 but it looks like this compatibility isn't included in the latest release on pypi. I have a package that includes lesscpy as a dependency and 3.5 compatibility has been a popular request so just wondering if you have any immediate plans to update the official pip-installable release? 

Thanks again, love the package.

items.title: python 3.5 support
items.body:
It appears that `lesscpy` doesn't work in python 3.5.

I get `TypeError: %x format: an integer is required, not float` when using it in 3.5 but not 3.4.  See an example full stack trace at https://github.com/dunovank/jupyter-themes/issues/28.

items.title: keyframe percentages are a syntax error
negated sub-expression fails with ValueError: too many values to unpack
items.body:
A rule containing a negated arithmetic expression, such as -(1+1), fails.

Minimal reproducer input:

```
.c { left: -(1 + 1) * 1; }
```

Traceback (from current master, 8088fe58):

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scripts/lesscpy", line 16, in <module>
    compiler.run()
  File "lesscpy/scripts/compiler.py", line 178, in run
    p.parse(filename=args.target, debuglevel=args.debug)
  File "lesscpy/lessc/parser.py", line 156, in parse
    self.post_parse()
  File "lesscpy/lessc/parser.py", line 168, in post_parse
    out.append(pu.parse(self.scope))
  File "lesscpy/plib/block.py", line 43, in parse
    inner = list(utility.flatten([p.parse(scope) for p in inner if p]))
  File "lesscpy/plib/property.py", line 39, in parse
    self.parsed = self.process(style, scope)
  File "lesscpy/plib/node.py", line 49, in process
    for t in tokens]
  File "lesscpy/plib/expression.py", line 42, in parse

ValueError: too many values to unpack
```

items.title: Support for writing to file
items.body: When using standard lessc an output file argument can be given (`lessc asd.less asd.css`), I ask for support of this feature in this port.

items.title: Explicit typechecking against str
items.body:
In python2.x, code should check against `basestring`. In 3.x, it should check against `str`. This is managed by the `six` library, which is meant to ease the transition between the two versions. There is currently broken code in about 5 files: 
- `lessc/parser.py`
- `lessc/scope.py`
- `lessc/color.py`
- `plib/call.py`
- `plib/expression.py`

In `lessc/scope.py`, there's a couple of comments that indicate that there's an attempt being made to make this library both python2 and python3 compatible. The comments seem to indicate that you should compare against `basestring` in py3 and `str` in py2. Not only could these comparisons be 
**GREATLY** simplified using `six`, but they are completely backwards. Py3 has no `basestring` and checking against `str` directly is dangerous in py2. I'm proposing adding a dependency upon `six` so that these problems can be transparently worked around without needing to resort to the `except NameError` check that is currently being done in `lessc/scope.py` (but nowhere else). I have forked the code and am working on integrating `six` where the explicit `str` checks are occuring. I will have a pull request before too long.

items.title: Bump version number and release to PyPi
items.body: With the relatively recent introduction of `lesscpy.compile()`, I feel the version number should be bumped (probably `0.10.2` or even `0.11`, if there're other changes that could stand to be pushed as well). In the lastest code however, the version number is still `0.10.1`. This could lead to confusion with regard to what version `lesscpy.compile()` was included in (since that function is aguably a VERY useful one).

items.title: AttributeError: 'Opt' object has no attribute 'spaces'
items.body:
Running compiling via python throws this error if no indenting options is passed. You can't even pass "spaces=True" as an option since it does not exists.

```
>>> lesscpy.compile(StringIO(u"a { border-width: 2px * 3; }"))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/simahawk/dev/plone/p4py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/lesscpy-0.10.1-py2.7.egg/lesscpy/__init__.py", line 18, in compile
    return f.format(p)
  File "/home/simahawk/dev/plone/p4py27/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/lesscpy-0.10.1-py2.7.egg/lesscpy/lessc/formatter.py", line 35, in format
    tab = '\t' if self.args.tabs else ' ' * int(self.args.spaces)
AttributeError: 'Opt' object has no attribute 'spaces'
```

The problem seems to be here https://github.com/lesscpy/lesscpy/blob/master/lesscpy/__init__.py#L4 whereas there's no "spaces" option and no default for indenting.

items.title: Numeric & formatting errors in hsla-to-rgba conversion
items.body:
If I have an HSLA colour such as `hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.5)`, it is converted to the follow rgba colour: `rgba(0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0)`. There are a few issues here:
1. The opacity value of hsla can take fractions of 1 as a valid alternative to percentages, but lesscpy only supports percentages. In fact, I believe some browsers don't support percentages.
2. A bug in utility.convergent_round which returns just integral_part when the fractional part is exactly equal to 0.5 (convergent_round(N.5, 2) should not return 0.0).
3. RGB portions are output as N.M, whereas they should be integers (out of 255). Chrome, at least, does not support fractional numbers here.

Here's a suggested fix for Color.hsla(): 

```
    def hsla(self, *args):
        """ Translate hsla(...) to color string
        raises:
            ValueError
        returns:
            str
        """
        if len(args) == 4:
            h, s, l, a = args
            if isinstance(l, str):
                l = int(l.strip('%'))
            if isinstance(s, str):
                s = int(s.strip('%'))
            if isinstance(a, str):
                if a.endswith('%'):
                    a = int(a.strip('%')) / 100.0
                else:
                    # Handle fractional values, not just percentages:
                    a = float(a)
            rgb = colorsys.hls_to_rgb(int(h) / 360.0, l / 100.0, s / 100.0)
            color = [float(utility.convergent_round(c * 255)) for c in rgb]
            color.append(round(a, 2))  # alternatively, fix convergent_round(N.5, 2) so that it returns more than just integral_part
            return "rgba(%d,%d,%d,%s)" % tuple(color)   # Output integers for RGB parts
        raise ValueError('Illegal color values')
```

items.title: lesscpy eating a space in some bootstrap rules
'encoding' is an invalid keyword argument
items.body:
When I just try to install master from a git working copy, I get this error:

```
user@machine:/src/git/Lesscpy> python setup.py install     
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 27, in <module>
    license=open('LICENSE', encoding="utf-8").read(),
TypeError: 'encoding' is an invalid keyword argument for this function
```

It works as soon as I remove the 'encoding' arguments from the open() calls. The python version used is 2.7.3.

items.title: Compiling Bootstrap 3
items.body:
I am trying to compile Bootstrap 3 less (https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/tree/master/less) using lesscpy but I am getting the wrong css output and a bunch of errors. You can see the whole output here:
https://gist.github.com/jtomasek/6366303

Most errors are related to issue #18.

Lot of errors are caused by semicolon-separated mixin parameters instead of using comma:

```
E: /home/jtomasek/bootstrap/less/mixins.less line: 47, Syntax Error, token: `;`, `;`
```

Bootstrap's reason to do that is fairly reasonable (see https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/issues/9014) so It would be nice if lesscpy suported this syntax.

Another issues are:
less variable beginning with comma

```
E: /home/jtomasek/bootstrap/less/variables.less line: 157, Syntax Error, token: `t_popen`, `(`
```

and `clip: rect(0 0 0 0);` declaration

```
E: /home/jtomasek/bootstrap/less/scaffolding.less line: 128, Syntax Error, token: `css_number`, `0`
```

items.title: Github organization
items.body:
Hi,

it probably makes sense to move robotis/Lesscpy to a github organization (i.e. lesscpy/lesscpy) so that we can better collaborate on it. I'd like to setup some web-hooks (like travis-ci) and enable nosetests amongst other things. Also, there are some open issues I'd like to address.

items.title: better error handling, please :(
items.body:
currently errors are silent unless you pass `-V` in which case verbosity goes to `stdout` merging with the `css` output. Also, the tool returns `0` when fails too, so it's impossible for an script to know if it worked.

requests (for better error handling) by priority:
1. verbosity to `stderr`
2. also error messages (to `stderr`!) when `-V` is not given
3. return 1 on failure so it can be used in scripts.
4. don't truncate previous knowledge on errors

Thanks!

items.title: @media only screen ....
items.body:
the following patch is required to support `@media only screen ...` lines

``` diff
--- a/lesscpy/lib/dom.py
+++ b/lesscpy/lib/dom.py
@@ -101,6 +101,7 @@ html4 = [
     'print',
     'screen',
     'all',
+    'only',
     'projection',
     'from',
     'to'
@@ -140,4 +141,4 @@ html5 = [
     'wbr',
 ]
 html = html4
-html.extend(html5)
\ No newline at end of file
+html.extend(html5)
```
